__data__.text: Nagaenthran a/l K. Dharmalingam is an ethnic Indian Malaysian, born in Ipoh on September 13, 1988, beginning his life in this world.

Nagaenthran, the text's subject, was born in Ipoh on September 13, 1988, and is an ethnic Indian Malaysian with three siblings: an elder sister, Sharmila, and two younger brothers, one of whom is named Navinkumar. Sadly, his father passed away while Nagaenthran was serving his death row sentence in Singapore.

Nagaenthran, the text's subject, was raised in Ipoh by his grandmother and relatives during his childhood as his mother, Panchalai Supermaniam, frequently worked outside the home and needed to leave him and his siblings in their care.

As Nagaenthran grew up, his mother, Panchalai, became his primary caregiver, although their communication was limited due to her job. Upon completing his secondary education at 17, he found employment at a factory, transitioning from being cared for to supporting himself.

After finishing school, Nagaenthran started working at a factory and became self-sufficient. However, he chose to move to Singapore for work, disregarding his family's concerns, particularly his mother's, who preferred him to stay in their hometown.
Upon moving to Singapore for work, Nagaenthran secured a position as a security guard, and despite being separated from his family, he made sure to regularly travel to Ipoh to see them.

Nagaenthran last visited his family in Malaysia during Deepavali in 2008, which was also the final time he was in his hometown prior to being apprehended for drug trafficking. This information comes from his sister.

Nagaenthran, then 20, was taken into custody by Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) officers for drug trafficking as he traveled from Malaysia to Singapore through the Woodlands Checkpoint in April 2009, according to his sister's account.

Nagaenthran, age 20, was found to be carrying a bundle of diamorphine (pure heroin) weighing 42.72g, which was attached to his thigh during a search by Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) officers when he was arrested for drug trafficking in April 2009, as per his sister's account.

Nagaenthran, at 20 years old, was caught with a large amount of diamorphine (pure heroin) on him during a drug trafficking arrest in April 2009. According to his sister's account, the diamorphine was found in a bundle tied to his thigh. Additionally, a companion of Nagaenthran, named Kumarsen, was also apprehended during the incident but was eventually released.

Nagaenthran, aged 20, acknowledged upon his arrest that he was aware of carrying drugs; he revealed that a Chinese acquaintance, referred to as "King," had concealed the drugs on his thigh to avoid detection. Kumarsen, another individual detained during the incident, was later released.

Nagaenthran, initially admitting to carrying drugs due to financial pressures from personal debts and his father's medical expenses, later withdrew his confession and claimed ignorance about the drug-laden bundle he had on him.

Nagaenthran, after confessing to drug trafficking because of financial difficulties, later retracted his statement and denied knowledge of the drug-filled bundle. He also asserted that King had previously attacked him and threatened to harm his girlfriend if he didn't agree to transport the drugs. Despite this, he faced the death penalty due to the large quantity of heroin found on him, surpassing the minimum threshold of 15g.

After confessing to drug trafficking, Nagaenthran later claimed he was coerced and unaware of the drugs, yet still faced capital punishment due to the significant amount of heroin found on him, leading to his conviction and death sentence on November 22, 2010.

The judge, Chan Seng Onn, rejected Nagaenthran's argument that he was forced to commit the drug trafficking crime, and determined that Nagaenthran was fully responsible for his criminal actions, which he undertook to settle his debts.

Nagaenthran's appeal was dismissed in July 2011 by a Court of Appeal panel consisting of Chan Sek Keong, V. K. Rajah, and Andrew Phang. He had sought re-sentencing and taken advantage of legal changes, but his efforts were unsuccessful. The judges held him accountable for his criminal actions in the drug trafficking case, rejecting his argument of coercion to commit the crime to settle debts.

In 2012, a year after Nagaenthran's appeal was rejected, Singapore introduced modifications to its death penalty regulations, leading to a halt on executions, including Nagaenthran's. This change came following his unsuccessful attempt to be re-sentenced by leveraging new legal provisions and the court's rejection of his coercion argument in the drug trafficking case.

In 2013, Singapore amended its death penalty rules, allowing judges to impose life imprisonment and at least 15 strokes of caning on drug traffickers acting as couriers, thereby granting judges discretion and halting executions, such as Nagaenthran's, following his failed re-sentencing attempt and coercion argument rejection.

In 2013, Singapore revised its capital punishment regulations for drug traffickers, introducing the possibility of life imprisonment and mandatory caning with a minimum of 15 strokes if the public prosecutor grants a certificate of substantial assistance to those who aid in disrupting drug trafficking activities. Another circumstance for life imprisonment is diminished responsibility, which applies when mental illnesses are diagnosed and proven to significantly affect the individual's mental capacities. These amendments led to the suspension of executions, such as Nagaenthran's, after his unsuccessful re-sentencing attempt and dismissal of his coercion argument.

In 2013, Singapore updated its capital punishment rules for drug traffickers, introducing the option of life imprisonment and mandatory caning with a minimum of 15 strokes if the offender provides substantial assistance in disrupting drug trafficking activities, as certified by the public prosecutor. Additionally, those with mental illnesses that significantly impair their mental capacities can be given life sentences instead of the death penalty. When the new laws came into force in January 2013, Nagaenthran sought re-sentencing due to his clinical intellectual disability and mental illness. If the revised laws had been in effect at the time of his offense, he would not have been eligible for the death sentence, and caning would not have been imposed.

In 2013, Singapore revised its capital punishment regulations for drug traffickers, introducing the possibility of life imprisonment and mandatory caning with a minimum of 15 strokes if the offender offers significant assistance in disrupting drug trafficking activities, as determined by the public prosecutor. Those with mental illnesses that significantly impair their mental abilities can receive life sentences instead of the death penalty. When the new laws took effect in January 2013, Nagaenthran applied for re-sentencing due to his clinical intellectual disability and mental illness. However, a psychiatric evaluation determined that he did not have either of these conditions. His case was returned to the original trial judge, Chan Seng Onn, for reconsideration in the High Court.

In 2013, Singapore updated its capital punishment rules for drug traffickers, allowing life imprisonment and mandatory caning with a minimum of 15 strokes if the offender provides significant help in stopping drug trafficking, as decided by the public prosecutor. However, Nagaenthran, who has an intellectual disability and mental illness, did not receive a more lenient sentence because a psychiatric evaluation found he did not have these conditions, and he was also ineligible for a certificate of substantial assistance from the Central Narcotics Bureau as he did not meaningfully aid in disrupting drug trafficking activities.

In 2015, Nagaenthran, who was previously sentenced to death for drug trafficking, applied for clemency, arguing that he had an intellectual disability, a low IQ, impaired executive functioning, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. However, his request was denied as he did not receive a more lenient sentence in 2013 because a psychiatric evaluation found he did not have these conditions, and he was ineligible for a certificate of substantial assistance from the Central Narcotics Bureau as he did not significantly aid in disrupting drug trafficking activities.

In 2017, Nagaenthran's application for re-sentencing was reviewed and rejected by the High Court. Four experts in psychiatry and psychology, including a defense-called professional, unanimously concurred that Nagaenthran did not have an intellectual disability.

In 2017, Nagaenthran's request for a revised sentencing was denied by the High Court, which noted his history of providing inconsistent statements about his educational background, seemingly to present lower qualifications during interviews. The court also concluded that Nagaenthran demonstrated manipulative and evasive behavior during the commission of his crime.

In 2017, Nagaenthran's appeal for a reduced sentence was rejected by the High Court, which highlighted his past of giving contradictory accounts about his educational background and his efforts to downplay his qualifications. The court also observed his deceitful and elusive conduct during his criminal act, such as attempting to prevent officers from searching him by claiming he worked in security to exploit the perception of security officers' trustworthiness.

In 2018, Nagaenthran's appeal was once again dismissed by the High Court, following a review by the Court of Appeal. This decision came after Nagaenthran, represented by his lawyer Eugene Thuraisingam, had sought to be re-sentenced. The court's ruling was influenced by Nagaenthran's history of providing inconsistent statements about his educational background and his attempts to downplay his qualifications. Additionally, his dishonest and evasive behavior during his criminal activity, such as trying to hinder officers from searching him by falsely claiming he worked in security to take advantage of their perceived trustworthiness, also factored into the court's decision.

In 2019, Nagaenthran, through his lawyer Eugene Thuraisingam, submitted two appeals requesting the Court of Appeal to reduce his sentence under recently implemented death penalty regulations. However, the five-judge Court of Appeal rejected both appeals on May 27, 2019. This decision was likely influenced by Nagaenthran's history of providing inconsistent statements about his educational background and his dishonest behavior during his criminal activity.

In 2019, Nagaenthran's appeals for a reduced sentence were denied by the Court of Appeal, which noted his history of inconsistent statements and dishonest behavior. The court found it challenging to trust his defense due to these factors, as they significantly affected his credibility and the reliability of his account of the crime.

In 2019, during Nagaenthran's appeals for a lighter sentence, a panel of five judges, including Sundaresh Menon, Belinda Ang, Andrew Phang, Judith Prakash, and Chao Hick Tin, concluded that, despite his lower-than-average IQ, Nagaenthran's mental capacity was not significantly affected, and he was still accountable for his criminal actions.

In 2019, when assessing Nagaenthran's appeals for a reduced sentence, the panel of judges found that, despite his lower-than-average IQ, he could still plan and organize tasks on a basic level and live independently. Moreover, Nagaenthran was aware that importing heroin was illegal and took steps to conceal the drugs to evade detection, indicating his understanding of the unlawful nature of his actions.

In 2009, Nagaenthran displayed manipulative and deceptive behavior when trying to prevent his arrest by narcotics officers, adding to the evidence that he understood the illicit nature of his heroin importation actions.

In 2009, Nagaenthran willingly engaged in heroin importation to settle debts, demonstrating a deliberate, calculated, and criminally inclined mindset. He was capable of evaluating consequences and understanding the illegal nature of his actions.

In 2009, Nagaenthran, after intentionally deciding to traffic heroin to pay off debts, showed a criminal state of mind that led to his ineligibility for a resentencing appeal. This decision followed his unsuccessful clemency petition and initial public attention. The summary conveys that Nagaenthran's actions demonstrated a clear understanding of the illegal nature and consequences of his actions, which resulted in the dismissal of his request for a resentencing and clemency.

After Nagaenthran's unsuccessful plea for a resentencing appeal, he sought clemency from the President of Singapore, Halimah Yacob, in 2020. If granted, this would have changed his death sentence to life imprisonment. However, his request was denied, finalizing his initial punishment. This sequence of events highlights Nagaenthran's awareness of the illegality and consequences of his drug trafficking actions, which led to the dismissal of both his resentencing and clemency appeals.

Nagaenthran's unsuccessful request for clemency in 2020 contrasts with the sole instance when clemency was granted in Singapore, which occurred in 1998. At that time, Mathavakannan Kalimuthu, a 19-year-old, received a pardon from execution despite being sentenced to death for murdering a gangster in 1996. This comparison emphasizes the rarity of clemency being granted in Singapore and further underscores the reasons behind Nagaenthran's unsuccessful appeal for clemency.

The text highlights the infrequent nature of clemency in Singapore by contrasting Nagaenthran's unsuccessful plea with the unique instance when it was granted to Mathavakannan in 1998. Mathavakannan, who was initially sentenced to death for murder, received a pardon and was released on parole in 2012 after exhibiting good behavior during his 16-year imprisonment. This comparison serves to underscore the challenges Nagaenthran faced in his own appeal for clemency.

The text describes the global interest in Nagaenthran's case, with numerous individuals and organizations advocating for his life to be spared, and the involvement of his mother, Panchalai Supermaniam, and family in appealing for his clemency. In a 2019 news article, a Malaysian human rights lawyer, N Surendran, criticized Singapore for imposing the death penalty on a man with mental disabilities, deeming it unjust.

In 2019, human rights lawyer N Surendran and lawyer M Ravi claimed that Nagaenthran's defense's psychiatric evidence was not given proper consideration during his trial, contrasted with the prosecution's psychiatrists' reports. This, they argue, resulted in an unfair trial. This critique was directed at Singapore's law minister, K Shanmugam.

In response to allegations of unfair treatment towards Malaysian drug traffickers, Singapore's law minister, K Shanmugam, asserted in 2019 that both local and foreign individuals are handled equally under the law in drug trafficking cases, countering the claims made by human rights lawyers N Surendran and M Ravi regarding insufficient consideration of defense psychiatric evidence for Nagaenthran compared to the prosecution's psychiatrists' reports.

In 2019, Singapore's law minister, K Shanmugam, stated that most Singaporeans support the use of capital punishment for drug traffickers. He suggested that it would be beneficial for both sides if Malaysian authorities apprehended drug offenders, as they would then be subject to Malaysia's legal system, avoiding the possibility of facing Singapore's death penalty. This statement reinforces the initial point of equal treatment under the law, as it implies that the application of the death penalty in Singapore is consistent and not biased towards locals or foreigners.

In 2019, Singapore's law minister, K Shanmugam, highlighted the importance of equal treatment under the law, mentioning that most Singaporeans support capital punishment for drug traffickers. In 2020, Singapore paused executions, including Nagaenthran's, at Changi Prison due to COVID-19 concerns, ensuring fair and equal legal treatment. This moratorium enabled Nagaenthran to extend his life by at least a year following his unsuccessful clemency appeal, up until 28th October 2021, in his hometown of Ipoh.

In late October 2021, Nagaenthran's family was notified through a letter from the Singapore Prison Service that his execution was set for November 10, 2021, ending the moratorium that began in 2020 due to COVID-19 concerns and giving him an extra year of life after his unsuccessful clemency appeal.

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) has informed Nagaenthran's family that they will assist and clarify any quarantine procedures and COVID-19 testing requirements for family members who wish to travel.

The Post-Appeal Applications in Capital Cases Bill, introduced on November 29, 2022, outlines a new process for inmates previously found to have misused court procedures in capital cases. A single judge will initially assess if these inmates can submit a post-appeal application due to new evidence. If approved, the application will proceed to a standard panel of three or five judges in the Court of Appeal. This reform is a part of the Singaporean government's strategy to tackle concerns about possible abuses in capital drug case procedures.

The Post-Appeal Applications in Capital Cases Bill, endorsed by many, including Opposition Leader Pritam Singh, establishes a new review process for inmates with a history of misusing court procedures in capital cases. The reform involves an initial assessment by a single judge and, if approved, a review by a panel of three or five judges in the Court of Appeal. However, Human Rights Watch criticized this law, claiming it aims to limit inmates' opportunities to contest their executions and access to final venues of justice.
